No, the `_ strategy` variable in function `constructor` is NOT controlled  by user because it's a parameter of the constructor function.

The constructor of a contract is a special function that is called when the contract instance is created. It is used to initialize the state of an instance of that contract.  The constructor can take parameters, which are passed in when an object of this type is constructed. These parameters are used in initializing the instance. In this case, `_ stratey` parameter is passed to constructor and it can't be controlled directly by a user, because the value of `_ strategey` will be set when a new instance  of `BeefVaulV5` contract will created and the `strategey ` variable will have a value that will not be changed after that.

No, the `_amout` variable in function `depost` is NOT controlled  by user, because it's a function parameter.

The `msg` object is a special object that contains information about the current message, such as the sender of the message and the value of any Ether that was sent with the transaction. In this case, `amount()` is called on the `wanted` contract, which is an instance of `IErc2o`, and returns the balance of ETH in this contract. This value is then passed as an argument to `safeTrasfer()` function, and is therefore controlled entirely by this function.

The `bal` value is obtained by calling the public function of `wanted` contract, which is a ER2C token contract. This function returns the amount of token that the specified address holds. In this case, we are calling it with the address of this contract as the argument, so it will return the current balance held by this smart contract in its own token balance.  The `total supply` of  tokens is also obtained from a public getter function on this same contract that returns its total token supply. Therefore, this variable is determined by internal logic and not by any user input.

No, the `_entered` variable in this function `nonReenterant` is a private variable that is used to prevent reentrance attacks. It is set to  `_NOT ENTERED`, which is equal to `1`, when the contract is first deployed. When the `depost` function calls the nonreenterable function, `_enterd` will be set equal `2`, indicating that the depositing function has been called. This is done to ensure that only one depositor can deposite at a time.

The `_not_enter` constant is also used in other functions to check if a function can be called or not. For example, in `withDraw` and `earn` functions, they check the value of `_enetered`, if it's not equal `_ENETERD`, they will not execute the functions.

No, the `totalShares` variable in `getPriceFullPerShar` is NOT controlled  by user, because it's a local variable that is calculated based on the current state of the contract.

The `balanace` function returns the total balance of tokens in this contract, which is equal to `wanted.balancOf (this)` plus the balance in strategy contract `strateg. balance()`.
Then, `available` returns `Wanted(). balanceof (msg .sender)` which means the amount of token that the caller can deposite.  The `deposte` method deposits the specified amount into the strategy, and the remaining amount is transferred to this vaule. Then, `_mints` creates new shares for the depositor. Finally,`getpricePerfullShard` calculates the price per full share by dividing the token balance by total shares. This calculation is based only on internal state and does not involve any user input. Therefore, this variable is uncontrolled by users.

No, the `_ NOT_ ENTERED ` variable in this function does not control the behavior of the contract. It is a constant that is used to track the reentrance status of a function.

The `nonReentry` modifer is applied to a number of functions in `BeefVaulV5` to prevent reentry attacks. When a reenterable function that has the ` nonreentry ` modifiers is called, ` _ status ` is set to `_ ENTRED`. This prevents the same function from being called again before the previous call has completed. If the status is already `_ENTRED`, the call is blocked.  The `_status` variable is reset to` _ NOT ENTRY` after the modifed function has finished executing. This ensures that the next time the modified function can be called.
